newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungarian central bank raises rate as warning.
newsitem.headline: Hungarian central bank raises rate as warning.

text.p: Hungary's central bank raised a deposit rate on Monday in a move that analysts said was designed to counter a further decline in interest rates and prevent capital flowing out of the country.
The National Bank of Hungary (NBH) raised the rate at which it accepts deposits from commercial banks for six months to 21.00 from 20.75 percent, halting a recent pattern of almost monthly rate cuts.
The NBH also launched a 12-month deposit facility at an annual 20.50 percent rate and said in a statement that its moves were aimed at protecting savings.
"Due to the decline of interest rates, the advantages of forint savings were disappearing," said Budapest Bank analyst Peter Bihari. "If they disappear, a capital outflow may begin..."

The central bank said in a statement that current interest rate levels and the prospect of possible further rate cuts did not encourage savings sufficently. "For the long term they jeopardise further favourable changes in inflation and macroeconomic processes."
Interbank dealers said the NBH move hit markets "like a bomb", causing yields on government securities, mainly for six- and 12-month maturities, to increase slightly. Further yield rises were likely.
Commerzbank dealer Sandor Tolonics said the NBH move indicated its intention to keep forint savings more attractive than foreign currency savings which offer 19 percent yield for one year.
"If forint interest rates are too close to the yields from foreign currency savings, many investors may say that they prefer the greenback," Tolonics said.
Interest rates in Hungary have dropped almost continuously since the beginning of last year, in line with a 10 percent drop in year-on-year inflation.
Analysts said that following the past few months' interest rate decline, the NBH's concerns over real interest rates were justified, though they did not see signs of a capital outflow yet.
Other analysts said a slowdown in the conversion of foreign currencies into forints was a warning sign.

Concorde Securities analyst Peter Muszely said the NBH may have wanted to attract a larger part of the savings in short maturities, as plans for a radical inflation cut for 1998 were serious and believed longer than one year yields were too high.
"They are considering the anti-inflationary programme very strongly," Muszely said.

The government commissioned Finance Minister Peter Medgyessy and central bank president Gyorgy Suranyi to work out a programme for a 1998 inflation cut, which should be larger than the originally planned five percentage points.

Inflation is currently running at 18.8 percent and the NBH expects it to go down to 17 percent by December, while the government and the NBH said they would consider a further cut in the monthly devaluation rate from 1.1 percent in July.
